content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! Lets start the meeting about review assignments
Here is the doc that @Wesley Wiser wrote: https://hackmd.io/LDKtEI-rTXKOw0PJKaeVcg
Maybe we should give 5-10 minutes for everyone to arrive and read it? It's not super long.
Yeah I was just thinking that: its short, but we do need to wait for more people to arrive anyway
I need to step out for a sec, but go ahead and put a :book: when you start reading, and a :checkered_flag: when you finish reading
11 reviewers meant to link something?
Fixed, thanks!
okay I’m back and it looks like everyone’s done reading
Should we go section by section perhaps?
so first up: does anyone have questions about the content of the doc as written?
(I’m not asking whether you agree/disagree, but whether you think you understood it all)
Also, as reference there are 13+23 "potential" reviewers (compiler+contributers)
I’m going to assume no one has any questions about their understanding of the document
so, next: Yeah, @Wesley Wiser , discussing section by section seems good
For idea 1, increase number of reviewers, I had a question there: would there be any benefit to trying to get people involved to participate in reviews even if they didn’t have r+ rights (yet) ?
Obviously that has a benefit as being an onboarding path for people to become compiler-contributors
but I was idly wondering if it also helps at all with the review process itself for the person who does have r+ rights. Or if it just introduces extra noise
I think the benefit is marginal
I think we should try to get more of the existing members to review things
I think I agree
I've definitely had random people point out that I've missed updating a comment or have a typo
right, I’ve seen a lot of that too. that’s not the kind of assistance I’m thinking of
and those are helpful (even if slightly)
at the heart of it, the person who r+’s a PR is taking on some amount of responsibility for it
I have a question or thought, I'm currently not in the reviewers list, I could be there but that would mean that I would have less of my reduced time to do other things
so they cannot in practice delegate to others
who aren’t themselves able to r+
But, I think it's helpful to encourage people that want to understand the code to try to review
Yes, I think it is a good onboarding path
Some projects discourage "drive by" reviews so if we want to encourage that, we should document our thoughts (perhaps in Contributing.md or somewhere similar).

Santiago Pastorino said:

I have a question or thought, I'm currently not in the reviewers list, I could be there but that would mean that I would have less of my reduced time to do other things

so I frequently end helping with some issues related to things that I have done or that Niko tells me can you help with this stuff
I'm also not sure, how frequent you get assigned to things there
I'm not sure if we are only talking about reviews or reviews + issues
but in any case, same thoughts apply
We’re only talking about reviews right now
not resolving open issues
Yeah, that's tricky. Reviewing can definitely take a lot of time but the more people we get on the review rotation, the less time it will take each person.

Wesley Wiser said:

Some projects discourage "drive by" reviews so if we want to encourage that, we should document our thoughts (perhaps in Contributing.md or somewhere similar).

The review policy mentions that it is always fine to leave a review, even if you won't be the final reviewer
right now, have many PRs do you people get assigned to per week?

Regarding the idea from @Vadim Petrochenkov of signing up all compiler-team and contributor members: Should we be perhaps expecting some minimum number of reviews from all team members and contributors?
I think that's really hard to quantify
because the amount of work from reviewing a given PR can vary so much, you mean?
If someone mentors + reviews one big PR, is that better/worse than 3 smaller PRs

pnkfelix said:

Regarding the idea from Vadim Petrochenkov of signing up all compiler-team and contributor members: Should we be perhaps expecting some minimum number of reviews from all team members and contributors?

I guess a policy about this may make sense
Its true. I guess I’m mostly thinking of setting a really low bar

Santiago Pastorino said:

right now, have many PRs do you people get assigned to per week?

Just going off memory, I think I get assigned about 5 - 8 reviews a week.
ohh yeah, that's a ton of stuff
encouraging that people spend x% of their contributing time on reviews seems like a good idea
I mean, if we go with adding teams to the highfive config, we could potentially expect that all compiler+contributors be on at least one team
It depends a lot on what the PRs are. Some are really easy to review/sign off on and others are quite large.
not necessarily the "main" teams
I think I like better the idea of being assigned to think that belong to your area of expertise or to things that you know or are involved, isn't that better?
I mostly want to make sure we avoid a situation
where some PR gets assigned
to someone else who is not actually keeping up
(I am an example of this)
like ... I'm not really involved with codegen/LLVM related stuff so assigning a very complex PR about that to me would not be the best thing to do :)
obviously the “right” answer is for me to either keep up or reassign
but the point is, I’d want some mechanism to correct for that scenario

Santiago Pastorino said:

like ... I'm not really involved with codegen/LLVM related stuff so assigning a very complex PR about that to me would not be the best thing to do :)

I think highfive tries to pick someone who's touched files in the changeset before so it's not entirely random.
ahh good to know :)

pnkfelix said:

but the point is, I’d want some mechanism to correct for that scenario

e.g. if the reviewer takes no action on a PR after being assigned, and does not even leave a comment saying “i’ll get to this on X date”, then should highfive reassign review after N days?
I think if we do have teams, then triage can be a bit more liberal about reassigning older/unreviewed PRs
Okay so the suggested answer here is manual triage, not mechanized?
I guess if we have subteams that are actively triaging their team’s workload, then that’s okay
I suppose mechanized reassignment works too

I believe a good idea may be to have a toml like the experts map with areas of the compiler and who is involved on each thing, and have highfive using that information to assign stuff + also sync all that with proper labels
The most important thing is that we don’t let things fall through cracks
The triage team has been pinging for reviews for a long time now but IIRC they have been intentionally more lax over the last year about bothering people for reviews.
maybe right answer is that the triage meeting should include PR’s that seem like they’re languishing waiting for review?
I mean, what would be the threshold for that?
a week? a month?
a week is too short IMO
agreed
Maybe we just look at the 5 PRs that have been least recently commented on?
but a month … a month might strike right balance. Or maybe 3 weeks.
3 weeks seems long enough

Wesley Wiser said:

Maybe we just look at the 5 PRs that have been least recently commented on?

So this will definitely put upper bound on the impact on triage meeting time
maybe this, plus a count of the number of PRs that have been waiting for review for over N weeks?
so that we try to keep ourselves honest about whether the number is going up or down?
Tracking the trend seems like a good idea.
@Santiago Pastorino @apiraino do either of you have any idea of how hard it might be to add the generation of these entries to the Meeting Agenda script?
Not count of number of unclosed PRs, but rather the histogram of days since open and since last comment
So, the 13 least recently updated PRs that are waiting on reviewer are all drafts...
I think we also need to spend some amount of meeting time looking at specific PRs or I don't think much will actually change outside the meeting. We're all pretty busy after all :)

Esteban Küber said:

Not count of number of unclosed PRs, but rather the histogram of days since open and since last comment

since last comment from anyone? or since last comment from an assigned reviewer? I think the latter is what I want.
From anyone

Wesley Wiser said:

I think we also need to spend some amount of meeting time looking at specific PRs or I don't think much will actually change outside the meeting. We're all pretty busy after all :)

Right. An explicit list of <= 5 PR’s does sound good to me.
Just this https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-asc+label%3AS-waiting-on-review

Jack Huey said:

From anyone

if the data is about days since comment from anyone, that doesn’t tell me whether review is making progress

pnkfelix said:

Santiago Pastorino apiraino do either of you have any idea of how hard it might be to add the generation of these entries to the Meeting Agenda script?

I don't think it will be very hard, but the infrastructure for that doesn't exist if I'm not wrong, you need to check comments and things, maybe if the PR is approved and certain things to see if there is a review and that's not what the agenda building process does at the moment, but sooner or later we need to have a way to check for all that anyway, so ...

Jack Huey said:

Just this https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-asc+label%3AS-waiting-on-review

can we filter drafts out of that list?
Per our earlier discussion, the assigned reviewer might not be the the one driving the review forward.
unsure

hm, it's worth noting I think that the meeting attendance is not too much larger or might be smaller than the current set of highfive reviewers, so reassigning in meetings might not be the best strategy

Jack Huey said:

unsure

maybe this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-asc+label%3AS-waiting-on-review+-is%3Adraft+

Wesley Wiser said:

Per our earlier discussion, the assigned reviewer might not be the the one driving the review forward.

So, should we try to change that? It's easy enough to reassign if needed later

simulacrum said:

hm, it's worth noting I think that the meeting attendance is not too much larger or might be smaller than the current set of highfive reviewers, so reassigning in meetings might not be the best strategy

I don’t know if the goal will be to actively reassign in the meeting, versus staying aware of status and assigning the meta-task of finding a new reviewer?

Jack Huey said:

So, should we try to change that? It's easy enough to reassign if needed later

Yeah, it might be nice if the metadata were accurate there
Yeah, maybe that meta-task is useful, not sure.
I think it should be the job of the assigned reviewer to re-assign if they don't expect to do the review themselves.
I find that the reasons for reviews to linger is because they are big, and reassigning them to someone else feels like throwing a hot potato at them
That's a valid point
That's another thing we should track: what kind of PRs are being resolved quickly
and which ones aren't
because I know that there are some... subtle parts of the compiler that require a lot of work in part of the reviewer, and I don't know what we can do about that

Esteban Küber said:

I find that the reasons for reviews to linger is because they are big, and reassigning them to someone else feels like throwing a hot potato at them

I think we should strive for re-assignment to be a conversation, not throwing a ball at someone
Some of the larger PRs might also be things that are right on the cusp of being MCP-worthy. Having that timeslot in the triage meeting gives other people the chance to provide that feedback.

That actually makes me wonder: the idea of only looking at the top five least recently commented — we would then add a comment after its discussed in the meeting, right? if for no other reason than to keep it from being enqueued in the next week’s meeting?
because we don’t want to be discussing the same N PR’s week after week, not in this case, I think
Makes sense
I don't think we need a strict rule that we'll always leave a comment, but if we've seen the same PR for 2 or 3 weeks in a row, we ought to leave some kind of comment I would think.
okay
Ideally there should be some resolution from the meeting. i.e. "still just needs a review", "actually blocked on ...", "needs to be reassigned", "needs an MCP"
Brings up a point: What do we do in the case that there is nobody that "can" review a PR? Or the person/people that have the proper knowledge are absent?
(or otherwise too busy)
I’ve been having thoughts about this. Both in the realm of “reviews that need doing” and also in the realm of “issues that need fixing"
depends on how important the PR is
i.e. if it's critical, somebody else might want to invest the time to learn about the topic
yes. In the end, I think we cannot rely on anything except having some people who push themselves to learn new things
but I know from experience that I don’t want to be doing that 100% of the time. Maybe some people like that, but I bet most don’t.
Agreed
yes, it also takes time to learn something new
yes.
Okay, so we're getting near the end of the meeting, should we try to come up with some actionable steps?
So, I don't think we addressed this directly, but it feels to me like there is agreement that we need to get more of the compiler team and/or compiler contributors in the review rotation?
more fine-grained highfive teams is something we should really do
(re: action items)
I can take that if nobody else wants to

Wesley Wiser said:

So, I don't think we addressed this directly, but it feels to me like there is agreement that we need to get more of the compiler team and/or compiler contributors in the review rotation?

I think so. That’s in part what I was going for when I asked if we should have a minumum bar for number of reviews
as part of creating the teams, we could ask compiler team members/contributors which ones they want to be on
Yeah, setting a minimum bar implies you need to be doing reviews :)

mw said:

more fine-grained highfive teams is something we should really do

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

pnkfelix said:

mw said:

more fine-grained highfive teams is something we should really do

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

I think so
seems like a good start
okay
Do we need a "minimum bar" now?
with a PSA: "you might find yourself in a review rotation. Yell if you want that to be changed"
there may be some people on it who aren’t actively working

pnkfelix said:

mw said:

more fine-grained highfive teams is something we should really do

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

yeah, that's what I meant, building areas from there would be nice :) and using that to assign stuff

pnkfelix said:

there may be some people on it who aren’t actively working

so we just need to make sure we stay on top of that

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

How's this different from @bors picking from the commit history?
you can re-assign to a team via the bot

pnkfelix said:

so we just need to make sure we stay on top of that

To this end: I think we have an action item to update our triage meeting agenda to include something about PR’s needing review

Esteban Küber said:

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

How's this different from @bors picking from the commit history?

I'm not sure how it works from commit history exactly, but I'd guess that most of us have touched a ton of areas because of some refactor we have made or something, but maybe you want to be in just a few areas

what experts do we have for maintaining that script? @Santiago Pastorino are you still well-versed in its construction? I know you said above its missing some infrastructure. But maybe just the hard coded link I wrote above would suffice.
Do we just want to assign everyone to some team? Or ask everybody if they can do reviews and which team(s) they want to be on?

Jack Huey said:

Or ask everybody if they can do reviews and which team(s) they want to be on?

I think I like this

pnkfelix said:

what experts do we have for maintaining that script? Santiago Pastorino are you still well-versed in its construction? I know you said above its missing some infrastructure. But maybe just the hard coded link I wrote above would suffice.

for the agenda I guess won't be hard to manually do it meanwhile we code something for the script

Jack Huey said:

Do we need a "minimum bar" now?

We can wait and see how things go. I admit, i’m not yet ready to set a minimum bar; I want to try to talk to the team members first about some of my ideas about how to deal with the issues/reviews that neeed “new expertise"

Santiago Pastorino said:

Esteban Küber said:

Will we just create the teams from the expert map?

How's this different from @bors picking from the commit history?

I'm not sure how it works from commit history exactly, but I'd guess that most of us have touched a ton of areas because of some refactor we have made or something, but maybe you want to be in just a few areas

also with time limitation it's different to be in the rotation for the whole PRs to the whole compiler than to just for instance be on MIR's PRs rotation
@Santiago Pastorino can I trust that you’ll take care of updating the meeting thing, or that you’ll make sure @apiraino does it?

Okay so, things to do going forward (correct me if I've missed anything):

  • Create more teams for the highfive config, basing on the expert map
  • Ask/encourage all compiler+contributors to be added to at least one team to do reviews
  • Add ~5 least recently reviewed PRs to weekly triage meeting
I'm not building the agendas currently but I can talk with @apiraino about this

Jack Huey said:

I can take that if nobody else wants to

This was in reference to “more fine-grained highfive teams”, right Jack?
yes
I can write an email and a post to send to all the compiler+contributors
One other quick thought: Do we want to encourage the triage team to go back to pinging reviewers for older PRs that are still waiting?

/me is late to the party.

mw said:

encouraging that people spend x% of their contributing time on reviews seems like a good idea

That feels like a job and I'm not sure people contribute to rust to feel like they're working a job necessarily.
@nagisa yeah I have thoughts on that too
the heart of my thoughts here are: there’s a significant subset of the compiler team now that is getting paid, at least for part of their work time, to contribute to rustc
well, I think there should be a healthy balance between writing code and reviewing code
I think it might make sense to explicitly identify the folks to are willing to be in the subset where they’re going to be given these obligations
To e.g. explore new terrain. Or to review languishing PR’s. etc.

I could also see a difference between compiler-team and compiler-contributors:

compiler team: by default you're added to highfive rotation but if you need to remove yourself, you can
compiler contributors: by default you're not added to highfive rotation but strongly encouraged to add yourself

pnkfelix said:

the heart of my thoughts here are: there’s a significant subset of the compiler team now that is getting paid, at least for part of their work time, to contribute to rustc

but this needs to be a conversation I have with people 1:1, I think. Because so many people are going to be in different places w.r.t. what their job expects them to be doing during their work day.
I find myself often in a place where I want to remain in a rotation but opt out for some time as a time off.
I definitely don’t want the compiler team membership in general to be requiring that kind of investment
I try not to assume, but I would think that people that are at least compiler-contributors are so because there is some area of the compiler that they want to contribute to
And contributing doesn't include just writing code, but reviewing it
okay the hour is up. I’ve added Action Items to https://hackmd.io/5BtjuenFTn6M74IDwLOjgw ; thanks to @Jack Huey and @Santiago Pastorino for accepting those.
and thanks of course to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!
Thanks all :) This felt productive!

@pnkfelix I've catched up with the meeting's note and @Santiago Pastorino quickly briefed me about adding the 5 topmost PRs waiting for review. I think we can have the "manual" version by next Wed and then we can code it into the triagebot so the list will be autogenerated (I think I can own this task)
okay thanks @apiraino !

Unrelated, I was also thinking about structuring a bit more the Action items list on hackmd
https://hackmd.io/5BtjuenFTn6M74IDwLOjgw

Such as the H2 headings are:

  • T-compiler Assigned
  • T-compiler Unowned
  • T-compiler in progress
  • T-compiler done
  • T-compiler deadlined

we don't want to replicate a full kanban board :) but would that make sense? Example, you completed one task and it's ticked (could be moved to "done"). I am in progress on one but it's not very visbile. Unsure about the progress of the other tasks
Maybe a kanban board is the right answer here
and I just need to garner experience with it

the main reason I used hackmd here is because I’m able to easily include it into other hackmd docs. So I now have a unified action item list for myself that includes the compiler-team and lang-team action items.
I'm all for using hackmd and not adding yet another PM tool :-) If you like the current stucture of the doc it's fine also for me.
I’m not necessarily happy with the structure. E.g. I have mixed feelings about the table at the end.
but that’s probably more that the state of the art w.r.t. markdown tables is still somewhat weak.

meanwhile I think I'll set the write permission on that file to "owners", currently is "signed-in users" (which I suspect is a bit too open? Not that that file can be interesting to a lot of people ...)
oh thanks, yes @apiraino , better to narrow scope there.
@pnkfelix @apiraino I think I can quickly code this
I guess this is more or less what we want https://api.github.com/search/issues?q=state:open+is:pull-request+-is:draft+label:S-waiting-on-review+repo:rust-lang/rust&sort=updated&order=asc&per_page=5
triagebot#1461
